item.title: Coronavirus quarantine rules: Differences across UK 'confusing', Grant Shapps says
item.description: The transport secretary admits varying approaches to international travel restrictions are frustrating.

item.title: HS2 rail project work begins with pledge of 22,000 jobs
item.description: Work on the controversial rail line formally starts on Friday, with Boris Johnson saying it will "fire up growth".

item.title: Alexei Navalny: Two hours that saved Russian opposition leader's life
item.description: Germany has revealed he was poisoned with Novichok. This is how events unfolded over Siberia.

item.title: Jessica Krug: George Washington University professor says she lied about being black
item.description: Jessica Krug, a white Jewish woman, admitted she had lied about being black for many years.

item.title: Batman filming paused after Robert Pattinson 'tests positive for coronavirus'
item.description: Lead actor Robert Pattinson has tested positive for coronavirus, according to US media reports.

item.title: Coronavirus: UK quarantine differences 'confusing' and a 'pivotal moment' for Leeds
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus outbreak this Friday morning.

item.title: Coronavirus: Leeds expected to become 'area of concern'
item.description: The city is expected to appear on the government's coronavirus watchlist as cases continue to rise.

item.title: Coronavirus: Italy ex-PM Silvio Berlusconi in hospital
item.description: Silvio Berlusconi has medical checks in Milan, after testing positive for coronavirus this week.

item.title: Brexit: 'Significant gaps' in UK's border plans
item.description: Haulage companies warn supply chains could be "severely disrupted" if problems are not sorted out.

item.title: Islamic State: Giant library of group's online propaganda discovered
item.description: Researchers say the "Caliphate Cache" is used to continually replenish extremist content on the net.

item.title: Pret a Manger offers coffee on a monthly subscription
item.description: Pret a Manager will allow customers to buy up to five drinks each day for a Â£20 monthly subscription.

item.title: Emily Hartridge: Deflated tyre 'caused Youtuber's e-scooter crash'
item.description: TV presenter Emily Hartridge was thrown under a lorry and killed in the accident, a coroner says.

item.title: The papers: 'Get UK flying' and BBC's social media 'crackdown'
item.description: Calls for coronavirus tests at airports and a speech from the BBC's new director general make the headlines.

item.title: Quiz of the week: What did Lady Gaga not win at the VMAs?
item.description: How closely have you been paying attention to what's been going on during the past seven days?

item.title: Belarus: The great-grandmother taking on President Alexander Lukashenko
item.description: As street protests in Belarus continue well into their fourth week, a 73-year-old has turned into an unlikely hero for demonstrators.

item.title: Migrant crisis: Rescue boat baby five years on
item.description: One of a million migrants who came to Europe in 2015, Stephanie was heavily pregnant when she was saved.

item.title: Mourning migrant workers killed in Beirut blast
item.description: The emotional impact of the city's deadly port explosion has been felt as far away as Ethiopia and Syria.

item.title: Reeta Chakrabarti: My Forgotten Army family ties
item.description: The news presenter discovers more about her father-in-law, just one of the men who belonged to the 14th Army in Burma.

item.title: Hair salon told it 'cannot advertise for a happy stylist'
item.description: The hair salon was told a job ad for a "happy" stylist would "discriminate against unhappy people".

item.title: Brexit: End tariffs on UK-made ice cream vans - Liz Truss
item.description: The government calls the vehicles a "great British export" and vows to fight for them in trade talks.

item.title: Strictly Come Dancing: Pop star HRVY joins 2020 line-up
item.description: The 21-year-old is added to the show's 2020 line-up, alongside Bill Bailey and Maisie Smith.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'Lockdown made my miscarriage far more traumatic'
item.description: Lockdown rules mean pregnant women must have scans alone - but what if there's bad news?

item.title: Ferguson and Kenosha: How two presidents responded to civil unrest
item.description: Two cities, two police shootings, two very different presidents. We take a look at their responses.

item.title: The New Mutants: Directorâs X-Men dream âcut in half by Hollywood realityâ
item.description: Director Josh Boone on the long and "bumpy" journey to get The New Mutants to cinema screens.

item.title: Why are there so few black tech entrepreneurs?
item.description: Black Lives Matter has shone a spotlight on policing, but also on other areas, like the tech industry.

item.title: Coronavirus: The US has not reduced its Covid-19 death toll to 6% of total
item.description: False claims about the Covid-19 death toll in the US have gone viral. Here's why they're wrong.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can schools afford Covid costs?
item.description: Schools face a number of financial challenges as more pupils return to school full-time.

item.title: How Covid-19 myths are merging with the QAnon conspiracy theory
item.description: Online and in real-life demonstrations, two viral conspiracy theories are increasingly coming together.

item.title: Profile: Former Australian PM Tony Abbott
item.description: The former Australian prime minister is being lined up to help the UK negotiate post-Brexit trade deals.

item.title: Why 600 books are being published on Thursday
item.description: Lockdown delayed the publication of many books, and authors now face big competition to get noticed.

item.title: Murray beaten by impressive Auger-Aliassime
item.description: Britain's Andy Murray is beaten in straight sets in the US Open second round by Felix Auger-Aliassime.

item.title: Bale half-time substitution planned - Giggs after win in Finland
item.description: Gareth Bale's half-time substitution during Wales' 1-0 win in Finland was planned beforehand, according to manager Ryan Giggs.

item.title: Rodrigo, Werner, Torres - how did new Premier League signings do in Nations League?
item.description: A host of new Premier League players were on show as Spain and Germany drew 1-1 in the Nations League - but what did we learn about them?

item.title: 'Majority of our best team are back' - England face Australia in T20 opener
item.description: England will field close to their best team "for the first time this summer" in the Twenty20 opener against Australia on Friday, says captain Eoin Morgan.

item.title: Williams battles into US Open third round
item.description: Six-time champion Serena Williams progresses to the US Open third round with a 6-2 6-4 win over Russian Margarita Gasparyan.

item.title: It will be tough to win another Grand Slam but I'll still aim for the stars - Murray
item.description: Three-time major champion Andy Murray says winning another Grand Slam will be "extremely difficult" but he will still "shoot for the stars".

item.title: UK travel restrictions: Are Portugal or Greece on the quarantine list?
item.description: Key holiday spots are being regularly added to the travel quarantine list as infection rates rise.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are available?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: When does the stamp duty holiday end?
item.description: The government has announced changes to stamp duty to help cut costs for anyone buying a home.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: The guidance on who should wear face coverings varies around the UK.

item.title: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Back to school: Four virus claims that parents should ignore
item.description: Children will be weighed to check lockdown obesity and other misleading online claims debunked.

item.title: Coronavirus: What will schools do if children get coronavirus?
item.description: Parents are being urged to send their children back to school for the autumn term

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the new local lockdown rules?
item.description: Restrictions are back in areas of the UK with rising coronavirus infections - but how do local lockdowns work?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK travel quarantine rules?
item.description: Travellers arriving from places like France and Spain must follow certain rules on entry to the UK.

item.title: What your children will see when they return to school
item.description: Children in the UK are returning to school for the autumn term, after Covid-19 disruption.

item.title: After six months at home, this separation will not be easy
item.description: An educational psychologist says children might be worried going back after such a long time at home.

item.title: Coronavirus and schools: What are the risks with reopening?
item.description: BBC health correspondent Laura Foster explains what schools are doing to keep pupils safe.

item.title: Coronavirus: Does reopening schools risk spreading coronavirus?
item.description: Children are at low risk from the disease, but concerns have been raised for teachers.

item.title: Coronavirus: Which sectors are hiring at the moment?
item.description: Jobseekers are having a tough time at the moment but some sectors are hiring and support is available.

item.title: Coronavirus: What happens when the furlough scheme ends?
item.description: Almost 10 million people have accessed the scheme, which closes in October.

item.title: Covid-19: Five ways to avoid catching the virus indoors
item.description: Good ventilation could be key to avoiding coronavirus this autumn as people spend more time indoors.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does Covid-19 test-and-trace work?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Coronavirus: What does my boss have to do to keep me safe?
item.description: The government wants more people to return to the workplace - but what precautions must employers take?

item.title: Coronavirus: Will the 'eat out to help out scheme' be extended?
item.description: Some restaurant chains say they will continue to offer a discount.

item.title: Europe lockdown: New coronavirus rules country by country
item.description: What are European countries doing to control new coronavirus outbreaks?

item.title: Flu: Why we still need to worry about it this winter
item.description: Drive-through vaccination clinics and extra staff are being considered for England's biggest flu vaccination programme.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: Many weddings were cancelled during lockdown, while some will have to change to meet the new rules.

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Coronavirus lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but who is responsible for enforcing them?

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key charts and maps explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world.

item.title: 'They wanted to drown me at birth - now I'm a poet'
item.description: Kuli Kohli has always used writing as a means of escape from the prejudice she has experienced as an Asian woman with cerebral palsy.
